After her hospitalization in ___ for the flu, her son notes
that she has actually been making leaps and bounds with physical
therapy, walking around with her back straight. As recent as ___
weeks ago she was able to stand and walk around in her garden,
which was a significant improvement. She is fairly independent,
and still drives to her own ___ appointments 2x/week/also
volunteers at ___ 1x/week; however her children help
her with the cooking- she enjoys Rotisserie chicken from ___.
When at home, she manages most her ADLs, but does not take a
shower unless son/daughter present.

However, over the past 2 weeks or so she has been more tired.
this is described as "feeling lousy", and as if she has no
energy. To give an example, ___ weeks ago she was able to go to
her garden and pick tomatoes; currently just the walk makes her
feel weary and tired. She has no focal weakness, no proximal
weakness, no trouble combing her hair or brushing her teeth. She
does feel a little achy sometimes in the AM, but has been told
that her inflammatory markers are normal, hence she is off
treatment for her rheumatologic disease. She notes that she 
never
sleeps through the night and naps during the day, but recently
has been napping more. She has no history of snoring, no
choking/gasping for air in sleep. Her appetite has been good, 
and
she has not lost weight, although she does suffer from acid
reflux for which she takes medications. She notes that her
bladder does feel uncomfortable sometimes, and she has increased
urinary frequency- this is in setting of decreased bladder
capacity after an unsuccessful uterine prolapse surgery. 
However,
she has no fevers, chills and U/A in ED was normal. She has no
abdominal pain. She has no nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman with history of atrial fibrillation on 
apixaban, hypertension, self-report of rheumatoid arthritis (but 
notes documenting polymyalgia
rheumatica), recurrent UTI on Bactrim prophylaxis who presents 
for evaluation of generalized weakness and fatigue.

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS:
# Fatigue: Patient presents with generalized fatigue and 
decreased exercise tolerance, without clear focal findings. She 
does have history of hypothyroidism, TSH normal. She is noted to 
have atrial fibrillation with slow ventricular response, however 
appears to have been long standing per discussion with
patient; nonetheless will maintain on telemetry in case there is 
correlation of bradycardia with symptoms.  Spoke with her 
outpatient cardiologist during admission, had stress echo in 
___, with no distinct abnormalities, some mitral 
regurgitation.  She has no evidence of electrolyte 
abnormalities. She has no muscle pain or weakness. She has no 
risk factors for HIV. She also has no
suggestive symptoms or findings to compel one to test for 
infection such as EBV/CMV/lyme. She denies any symptoms 
consistent with obstructive sleep apnea. She denies depression.  
Her only recent medication change is switching to apixaban from 
warfarin, do not feel this is causing fatigue.  She is on
furosemide for past history of some fluid overload.  She does 
have documented history of PMR and has been off steroids, CK 
normal, ESR pending, CRP normal.  Also considered etiologies 
such as adrenal insufficiency given that she
had previously been on chronic steroids, however, this was 
tapered off ___ year ago and time course does not fit.  For now, 
she denies any cardiac disease other than atrial fibrillation, 
had chest pain, but ECG and troponins reassuring.  Low voltage 
EKG is not new finding.  B12 was normal.  LFTs were normal.  ___ 
cleared for home discharge.   Telemetry did not reveal any 
arrhythmia other than known atrial fibrillation.  ESR is pending 
and will need to be followed up.  She will follow up with her 
PCP and cardiologist.

CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS:
# Hypertension: Patient on lisinopril at home. She notes that 
she has not taken this for a while as SBP in 120s off this 
medication. Restarted during admission, and should be used if 
hypertensive at home.

# Atrial fibrillation: Continue home apixaban 5 mg BID (note 
weight is >60 kg per patient. She is not on rate control agents, 
nor does she need them.

# GERD: Continued PPI

# Hypothyroidism: Continued home Levothyroxine Sodium 25 mcg 
PO/NG DAILY 

# COPD v. asthma: Patient carries diagnosis of asthma, however 
is on Breo at home which is not classic for asthma, although 
note she is a non-smoker. No PFT in system to document whether 
defect is reversible. She was provided Duonebs during admission, 
and will continue her home medications on discharge.

# Glaucoma OS
